history.content:
I think you should take EE C106B + CS 162, maybe also EE 192 if you have the time.

For your specific question:
"How important 162 or 106b would be for some sort of robotics career"
I will leave it to people who are much more knowledgeable in robotics to answer.

————————————————————————

This depends on what aspect of robotics you would like to learn. Obviously, EECS 106A is the intro class where you learn the math and physics of robot manipulation, but after the general introduction, you should choose between hardware and algorithms. 

EECS151 is generally useful if you want to leverage the hardware. If you want to learn how to build sensors and actuators for your robot, there are several IC-related classes (105,140,147).

If you are more interested in the control theory, you should choose from EE 106B, 128, 221A, 222, 223, which will give you a variety of tools for analyzing and designing system in general. Optimization is also an integrated part of control theory, so EECS127 is also useful. With a solid understanding of control and optimization, you should also consider some ML courses on algorithms. Besides CS189, there are graduate courses such as CS280, 287.

------

I personally think that 106B was the best class I took at berk, but you should see how you like 106A before you decide on 106B. Robotics is a somewhat hard field to get into, and most people in the field have graduate degrees (at least on the algorithmic side). 106B is definitely designed for students at least considering grad school and is very research focused, but I think it has a good balance of theory and implementation of said theory (I designed a lot of the curriculum and thus am very biased).

If you go into robotics without a graduate degree, it's likely that you'll be doing software engineering or hardware engineering, rather than actually working on the robotics algorithms directly, so your biggest priority should be becoming a good software (hardware) engineer and doing a 106A project that you can show off. More robotics-focused classes are icing on the cake.

I think you should take EE C106B + CS 162, maybe also EE 192 if you have the time.

For your specific question:
"How important 162 or 106b would be for some sort of robotics career"
I will leave it to people who are much more knowledgeable in robotics to answer.

children.subject:
I think EE 123 is also important to take, and I am taking it next spring :)

Since your time is limited, I wouldn't take EECS 151 if it is for robotics focus.

I also want to take EE 192 next spring, but I am afraid that EE 192 is too much to take along with other classes.

How do you feel in EE 192 this semester? 

I would like to get some info and advice from you.

192 is a great class. It can have a couple of logistic problems here and there, but thats just what you get with small classes. Overall, highly recommend if your looking for a class that is application focused, and you have the time for it. Before they shut down lab classes, we finally got to see our car drive on a track with our custom made line tracking algorithms. Now we are just running simulations to finish off the semester, but the majority of circuit building was done before school was moved online. In a normal semester you would get your pcbs ordered and manufactured, but we didnt get to do that, but we still built the circuits in a pcb editor. The TAs are good, and Fearing is a knowledgeable professor.

(OP) I am taking 192 currently, and it was pretty fun. I was also considering ee151 and cs 152 because I liked 61c, but again, not sure if I would take them or have the time because they are very time consuming. Similar with ee123 in the spring.

history.content: Hello! I am graduating next spring and would like some recommendations for classes for a semi-robotics focus. I am taking 106a, and 126 next semester, and 189 in the fall. I want to also take 184 in the spring, but other than that, im pretty open to 2 more techs. I was wondering how important 162 or 106b would be for some sort of robotics career. At this point im kind of just taking classes that interest me because Im almost done with my degree requirements. Any recommendations?
history.subject: Some recommendations for classes and robotics
